content:
• Friday, November 4, 2016
  • VEON

    VimpelCom planning shift from older telco to Internet player

    • Buffeted by events over the past year, VimpelCom (VIP -2.6%) is planning a radical overhaul and transition from the older-school telecom it is today into an Internet player, its CEO tells Reuters.
    • "Fundamentally, we think the industry is at a crossroads," says Jean-Yves Charlier. "Telcos have an opportunity to really (join) the Internet age. And that's where we see our whole strategy going."
    • The company plans to shift from selling voice and data calls to an app-based platform where users can communicate for free -- and monetize through revenue sharing with apps like Uber.
    • Client data may be the key to drawing revenue streams from apps particularly including banking and messaging.
    • The company's Italian unit Wind Telecomunicazioni (set to merge with Hutchison's Three Italia) has been testing a free messaging app this week, and it expects to roll it out across Italy by Christmas (and, it hopes, more than dozen markets by the end of 2017). Unlike WhatsApp, VimpelCom's Veon will be zero-rated so it doesn't incur data charges.
    • Overall, as access fees shrink across the industry, VimpelCom is seeking a piece of the $200-$300/month that customers can spend on phone-based Internet services. "We are putting a major bet on overhauling the whole plumbing of the company," Charlier says. "The future is about engineering capabilities around data."
     
     
     
     
    | 6:42 PM | 1 Comment
  • N

    NetSuite active after hours with Oracle deal closing in on expiration

    • Shares in NetSuite (NYSE:N) were volatile all day, though have at present moved 4% upward to $94 in extended trade.
    • A form 4 SEC filing has additionally come through today with T. Rowe Price, NetSuite's largest unaffiliated shareholder, unloading 47K shares at a $89.27 level, bringing overall ownership to 14.34M.
    • Minimum tender conditions relating to the deal call for 20.4M of 40.8M total unaffiliated shares.
    • T. Rowe Price has voiced support for a buyout at $133 per share while Oracle's (NYSE:ORCL) kept firm at $109.
    • The potential merger, set to terminate by end of day, remains on watch until anything conclusive is announced.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:51 PM | 18 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: SPPI +6.5%. LPLA +3.4%. NUS +3.2%. FDC +3.0%. AYA +2.3%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: ALR -5.1%. DHT -4.1%. GNBC -3.2%. AGO -2.4%. NRF -2.0%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:37 PM | 11 Comments

  • Weekly ETF Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: VXX +13.5%. GDX +5.3%. GDXJ +5.0%. PSLV +4.3%. SLV +3.5%.
    • Losers: GAZ -16.6%. UNG -11.4%. OIL -10.3%. BNO -10.0%. USO -9.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:14 PM
  • SSP

    Scripps slips 3.2% after Q3 misses expectations

    • E.W. Scripps (NASDAQ:SSP) joined a market slide and closed down 3.2% after it missed expectations with Q3 earnings despite swinging to a gain from continuing operations.
    • Revenues grew 23%, mainly due to gains in retransmission revenue, political advertising and growth in its digital businesses.
    • Revenue by segment: Television, $197M (up 25%); Radio, $19.3M (down 5.4%); Digital, $15.8M (up 45%).
    • In TV, retrans revenue was up $16.8M. Advertising revenues: Local, $77.9M (flat on same-station basis); National, $35.5M (up 2.2% on same-station basis); Political, $26.9M vs. year-ago $4.3M.
    • In Q4 expectations: TV revenue is seen up in the mid-30% range; radio revenue down in low single digits; and digital revenue up in the low-40% range.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:05 PM
  • ATVI

    Activision -3.9%, but bullish analysts double down

    • Activision Blizzard (NASDAQ:ATVI) is 3.9% lower today after issuing some (not unusual) soft guidance for the holidays, though analysts aren't short on seeing upside ahead.
    • Firms reiterated their Buy ratings and three raised price targets: Baird, Cowen and Wedbush. Baird bumped its price target to $50 from $46; Wedbush, meanwhile, raised to $53 from $48, implying 27% upside from today's lower price.
    • That dim guidance comes even with today's release of the latest in its annual smash franchise, Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare. The cautious outlook is "likely due to the company factoring in a healthy layer of conservatism around Call of Duty," says Piper Jaffray's Michael Olson, who has a price target of $51. "Activision management has historically under-promised and over-delivered, exceeding its original EPS guidance on average by 19% in the past 7 years."
    • Jefferies' Brian Fitzgerald sees "large new opportunities in e-sports, in-game advertising, and micro-transactions ... Advertising is a potential billion-dollar business and is not included in Street estimates."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:57 PM | 45 Comments
  • IOC

    InterOil -6% as Canada court sides with former CEO in merger dispute

    • InterOil (IOC -5.8%) plunges after an appeals court in Canada upheld a challenge lodged by former CEO Phil Mulacek and overturned the Supreme Court of Yukon's approval of ExxonMobil's (XOM +0.1%) pending $2.5B takeover of the company.
    • IOC says the current deal represents compelling value for its shareholders, and that the two companies are determining a path to closing the transaction.
    • Mulacek, who stepped down in 2013 but still owns IOC shares, has called the offer from XOM - which would see IOC shareholders receive $45/share of IOC paid in XOM shares - "vastly inadequate."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:45 PM | 9 Comments
  • ENDP

    Big bounce for specialty pharma

    • The major averages are flat, but the XLV is higher by 1%, and the IBB by 2.15% as pharmaceutical names rebound from yesterday's plunge.
    • Sending the stocks down was word of charges about to come from the government following a two-year antitrust probe, but public outrage goes with the territory, says Zacks' Tracey Ryniec, noting the prices - with some at just four or five times earnings - are getting seriously cheap.
    • Among those moving today: Endo International (ENDP +1.8%), Perrigo (PRGO +3%), Mylan (MYL +2.6%), Allergan (AGN +3.4%), Cara (CARA +23.8%), PTC (PTCT +20%), Novavax (NVAX +18.9%), Flex (FLKS +14.5%), Cerus (CERS +14.9%), LifePoint (LPNT +2.9%), and Halyard Health (HYH +3.2%).
     
     
     
     
    | 3:38 PM | 19 Comments
  • GPRO

    GoPro coverage largely unmoved on Q3 report

    • Despite the dismal results and projected outlook.
    • Cowen and Company, Pacific Crest Securities, Dougherty & Company, Stifel and Baird remain sidelined with respective Market Perform, Sector Perform, Neutral, Hold and Neutral ratings. Raymond James and Wedbush Securities, on the positive end, both reissue GoPro at Outperform with respective lowered price targets ($16 to $13, $17.50 to $12) [current price $10.78]. BlueFIn Research partners, on the negative side, considers the quarter "frightening."
    • GoPro (NASDAQ:GPRO) shares today have spanned a wide range of intraday movement, at one point rising by over 24%, and into overall positive territory. At present, however, trading has drifted lower by 9% on a one-day term.
    • N.B. Ambarella (NASDAQ:AMBA) +2.7%
     
     
     
     
    | 3:33 PM | 10 Comments
  • ASRT

    Depomed pops higher on takeover rumor

    • The source doesn't have the most reliable reputation, but nevertheless Depomed (DEPO +3.8%) is on the move as Interconomia.com reports Mallinckrodt (MNK +2.1%) as having won the bidding for the company with a $2.6B offer.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:24 PM | 27 Comments
  • LIND

    Big bounce for Lindblad Expeditions after earnings beat

    • It's been a rough run for the cruise ship operator, so it didn't take a lot of good news to send the shares sharply higher.
    • In addition to the beat, the earnings call was a positive one, says Seeking Alpha contributor and Lindblad (LIND +7.2%) bull Dane Capital Management. Year-to-year bookings have been trending higher for seven straight months, and with lead times extending out to 12 months, this in conjunction with new ships (with better margin profiles) sets up healthy growth into H2 of 2017.
    • Dane notes the company remains woefully underfollowed, with just two sell-siders covering - neither of which bothered to appear on the earnings call. Management appears to agree it's a good time to buy as it lifts its repurchase program to $35M from $20M.
    • Lindblad Expeditions Earnings Center
     
     
     
     
    | 3:18 PM

  • Technology - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 3:00 pm

    • Gainers: HDP +22%. IMMR +17%. ECOM +17%. FEYE +16%. TRUE +16%.
    • Losers: ABTL -30%. MRVC -25%. NPTN -23%. COGT -22%. CSOD -19%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:00 PM
  • HIL

    Hill International -17% after delaying release of Q3 results

    • Hill International (HIL -17.1%) plunges as much as 34% after saying it will delay the release of its Q3 and YTD financial results, which had been scheduled for today.
    • Hill says it is in continuing discussions with its accounting firm about the accounting treatment of certain accounts receivable, which could have a material effect on its financial position and results of operations.
    • Separately, Hill says it won a five-year contract from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to provide project delivery and advisory services in connection with the Newark International Airport.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:53 PM
  • CHK

    Chesapeake Energy can double to $11, SunTrust says

    • Chesapeake Energy (CHK -1.5%) can double from current levels to $11, SunTrust analysts say, following the company's strong Q3 results that featured higher than expected production and lower costs.
    • SunTrust says CHK has made substantial financial progress in the past year, with the company shoring up its liquidity and leverage, and materially simplifying its balance sheet.
    • The firm believes CHK's leverage is still higher than the peer group average, and it forecasts a $300M cash flow outspend next year, but continued operational efficiencies and lower well costs should further boost returns and likely push cash flow positive in 2018.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:44 PM | 39 Comments
  • NDLS

    Another turn lower for Noodles after earnings

    • Noodles (NDLS -7.8%) falls lower after Q3 results fail to impressive investors.
    • Comparable restaurant sales were down 0.9% during the quarter at company-owned units.
    • Average unit volumes declined $24K to $1.071M, compared to a year ago.
    • Restaurant contribution margin decreased 280 bps to 12.4% of sales.
    • Shares of Noodles traded as low as $4.05 earlier.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:36 PM | 2 Comments
  • FLR

    Fluor -12% after huge Q3 earnings miss, weak outlook

    • Fluor (FLR -12.4%) plunges after reporting Q3 operating earnings of $0.03/share, far below the analyst consensus estimate of $0.87,
    • Q3 results included a $1.10/share ($154M) after-tax charge for estimated cost increases on the $6B Chevron Phillips petrochemical expansion in Baytown, Tex., but earnings would have been lower Y/Y even without the charge.
    • Chairman and CEO David Seaton says FLR is disappointed in the construction progress on the project that required the charge, which the company had agreed to build for a fixed price, and confirms that FLR will take a net loss on the entirety of the project.
    • FLR cuts its FY 2016 earnings guidance, seeing EPS of $2.20-$2.40, far below analyst consensus $3.31 as well as an earlier outlook for $3.25-$3.50; FY 2017 EPS is seen at $2.75-$3.25, vs. $3.50 analyst consensus, which assumes continued challenges in its commodity focused segment.
    • At least four research firms downgrade the stock following the results.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:33 PM | 9 Comments
  • OLED

    Universal Display +6.5%, highlights ramping OLED market in Q3 report

    • Results – revenue $30.21M ($2.74M below estimates), EPS $0.03 ($0.01 above estimates), $1.5M net loss (vs. $7M net income Y/Y)
    • FY 2016 projections – revenue $190M-$200M (consensus $195.2M)
    • Universal Display (NASDAQ:OLED) EVP and CFO Sidney Rosenblatt: "Leading panel makers are building capacity for the next wave of high volume OLED production to begin ramping next year, OEMs are building new OLED product roadmaps, and we are building our infrastructure to meet the growing needs of our expanding customer base . . . As we anticipate resuming our growth trajectory in 2017, we continue to build up our core competencies. The display and lighting industries are evolving, and we believe we are well positioned to continue to play a pivotal role in the OLED market’s future. We have expanded our global footprint, increased our headcount to approximately 200 employees, bolstered our IP portfolio to over 4,200 issued and pending patents worldwide, and continue to broaden our rich portfolio of proprietary OLED technologies and phosphorescent materials. These investments, in addition to our other strategic initiatives, buttress our committed path of continuous innovation and next-generation solutions, our strong leadership position in the OLED ecosystem, and our confidence in the long-term growth path of OLEDs."
    • Share price summary – 1-month, +5%; 3-month, -21%; 1-year, +51%
    • Earnings call transcript
    • 10-Q
     
     
     
     
    | 2:26 PM

  • Energy/Materials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm

    • Gainers: GLF +18%. BRS +18%. LXU +15%. SNMX +16%. WLB +12%.

    | 2:18 PM
  • CLMT

    Calumet Specialty Products upgraded at Credit Suisse on valuation

    • Calumet Specialty Products (CLMT +3.2%) is upgraded to Neutral from Underperform with a $5 price target at Credit Suisse, which says units have fallen too far.
    • The firm says CLMT still has a great deal of risk and bankruptcy is not impossible, especially in the event of an economic downturn, but believes there is now potential equity upside for CLMT, even using a conservative estimate of ~$230M of annual EBITDA during 2017-20.
    • Credit Suisse leaves its $5 target unchanged for now, but note that if CLMT is able to hit the $350M-$400M EBITDA implied by $150M-$200M of targeted self-help, it would add another $4-5$/unit of additional upside beyond its target.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:57 PM | 15 Comments
  • TPCO

    Tronc: Could agree to 'different' Gannett deal

    • Tronc (TRNC +0.3%) Chairman Michael Ferro says there's room for "a different type of deal" with Gannett (GCI +4.1%), all in the immediate stock-shaking aftermath of Gannett walking away from a hostile bid for the publisher.
    • Discussions broke down on speculation that an $18.75/share price bid wasn't enough for Ferro, though the two companies were reported to have largely agreed on that price. Tronc shares have dropped 20.5% since Tuesday to $9.57.
    • Ferro said Gannett ended the deal after running into "an unexpected delay" in financing. Last week it was reported that banks were withdrawing funding for the takeover. But Gannett says that several financing options were available.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:44 PM | 1 Comment
  • AMZN

    Rumblings of activist investor action at Whole Foods Market

    • Whole Foods (WFM) is up 1% after shares were briefly halted following a volume spike.
    • Bloomberg reports that a major shareholder has met with potential activist firms to push for a sale or significant strategy reset. Concerns over inventory and vendor management were cited.
    • Shares of the grocery store chain were in negative territory earlier in the day after Bank of America Merrill Lynch downgraded WFM to Underperform and set a price target of $25.
    • After bouncy trading, Whole Foods is nearly level for the week.
    • Previously: Whole Foods higher after EPS beat, dividend hike and sole CEO switch (Nov. 2)
    • Previously: Whole Foods Market feels the heat from new rivals (Nov. 3)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:25 PM | 17 Comments
  • MDCA

    MDC Partners -58% as it explores potential sale

    • Ad firm MDC Partners (NASDAQ:MDCA) has plummeted, down 58% today, after a disappointing earnings report and now news that it's exploring strategic options -- reportedly including a sale.
    • The firm's been subject to an SEC investigation over non-GAAP earnings characterization. A slight decline over the past month has become drastic with the earnings release.
    • MDC CEO Scott Kauffman had said that the scope of strategic talks was to "explore and evaluate our capital structure," while Omega Advisors' Leon Cooperman says that mandate "should be broadened."
    • Private-equity firms could be good buyer candidates, allowing for a more private restructuring of the company, sources told the WSJ.
    • MDC owns ad agencies including Crispin Porter + Bogusky and 72andSunny.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:07 PM | 1 Comment

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: CFMS +39%. CBK +31%. OTC:DCTH +24%. BRS +23%. HDP +21%. OSTK +21%. AIRM +20%. CARA +20%. CTRL +19%. NVAX +18%.
    • Losers: MDCA -57%. IVTY -45%. ASPN -30%. ABTL -30%. MRVC -25%. NPTN -25%. LILAK -23%. TCCO -20%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:58 PM | 1 Comment
  • ECA

    Encana upgraded at RBC on plan to grow oil and gas derivatives by 60%

    • Encana (ECA +1.5%) is upgraded to Outperform from Sector Perform with a $13 price target at RBC Capital, which says ECA's better than expected Q3 results reinforce its confidence in the company's ability to deliver high margin oil and condensate growth during 2016-21.
    • RBC says ECA’s five-year plan suggests it will grow production by 60%, mostly due to activity in the Permian and Montney plays, adding that the company also wants to double margins in its upstream business and improve cash flow by 300%.
    • RBC believes ECA "has some of the best real estate on the block when it comes to North American resource plays and possesses solid execution capability."
     
     
     
     
    | 12:58 PM
  • BT

    After Brexit, Deutsche Telekom mulls selling 12% BT stake

    • More Brexit fallout: Deutsche Telekom (OTCQX:DTEGY -0.7%) is thinking of selling its 12% stake of British incumbent telecom BT Group (NYSE:BT), Reuters reports, depending largely on what kind of deal the UK strikes to get out of the European Union.
    • BT is off 1.8% in U.S. trading; it closed down 2.6% in London.
    • That stake is worth about £4.4B ($5.5B), and Deutsche Telekom may see that money as better deployed elsewhere with a falling pound and projections for shrinking growth.
    • The company (BT's biggest shareholder after the EE acquisition) can't sell the stake through normal means due to a lock-up lasting until August 2017; it can agree to an off-market deal with investors.
    • DT is also rumored to be selling its British IT and consulting business, run through its T-Systems unit; it once tried to merge that business with BT's Global Services.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:51 PM
  • SYMC

    Symantec -8%, Q3 guide light

    • Results – revenue $1.015B (+12% Y/Y), EPS $0.30 (vs. $0.29 Y/Y), operating margin 29.2% (vs. 31.2% Y/Y), net income $192M (vs. $196M Y/Y)
    • Segment revenues – Consumer Security $405M (-4% Y/Y), Enterprise Security $610M (+26% Y/Y)
    • Geographic revenues – International $502M (+19% Y/Y), U.S. $513M (+6% Y/Y), Americas $571M (+6% Y/Y), EMEA $253M (+13% Y/Y), Asia Pacific & Japan $191M (+31% Y/Y)
    • Q3 projections – revenue $1.070B-$1.090B (consensus $1.11B), Enterprise Security revenue $675M-$690M, Consumer Security revenue $395M-$400M, operating margin 27%-28%, EPS $0.27-$0.29 (consensus $0.30), tax rate 29%
    • FY 2017 projections – revenue $4.040B-$4.120B (consensus $4.08B), operating margin 27%-29%, EPS $1.12-$1.18 (consensus $1.12), tax rate 29%
    • Symantec (NASDAQ:SYMC) CEO Greg Clark: "We have made remarkable progress in the short time that Blue Coat and Symantec have been combined. We completed the first phase of delivering our Integrated Cyber Defense Platform, our sales force is now enabled to sell the Company’s combined portfolio, and our cost savings and synergy initiatives are tracking ahead of schedule. There’s more integration work ahead, but I’m confident about our future. Since closing in August, we’ve brought to market two significant new solutions integrating the Data Loss Protection and Cloud Access Security Broker technologies and shipping Symantec Endpoint Protection 14. I’m particularly proud of the value we are providing our existing customers by integrating artificial intelligence with two of the largest threat databases in the world. This integration has improved our existing products which are now blocking an additional 500,000 attacks per day across the endpoint and network."
    • Share price summary – 1-month, -7%; 3-month, +11%, 1-year, +12%
    • Prior quarters overview
    • Earnings call transcript
    • Earnings call slides
     
     
     
     
    | 12:48 PM
  • CFMS

    ConforMIS Q3 top line up 34%; net loss narrows; shares up 37%

    • ConforMIS (CFMS +37.4%) Q3 results ($M): Total Revenues: 18.6 (+34.2%); U.S.: 15.0 (+42.9%).
    • Net Loss: (12.8) (+25.4%); Loss/Share: 0.31 (+31.1%).
    • Consensus view was non-GAAP EPS of ($0.36) on revenues of $18.3M.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:32 PM | 3 Comments
  • GCAP

    Gain Capital blasts off despite 'challenging' quarter

    • Income was way down in Q3 - with adjusted EBITDA of $3.3M vs. $30.1M from one year ago - but it's appearing to be more than priced in as Gain Capital (NYSE:GCAP) surges 16.4% this session.
    • CEO Glenn Stevens doesn't sugarcoat it: "The challenging market conditions of the third quarter resulted in lower than expected average daily volumes and revenue capture." He does note an improving volatility outlook thanks to Brexit, the election, and interest rate uncertainty.
    • There's also a one penny increase in the quarterly dividend to $0.06 per share, and approval of a buyback of up to $30M.
    • Gain Capital Earnings Center
     
     
     
     
    | 12:29 PM | 12 Comments
  • NRG

    Power plant operator profits dimmed by low wholesale prices

    • Companies that sell electricity to utilities have reported slim profits or losses for Q3 compared to a year ago, as they continue to be hurt by falling prices for wholesale power and natural gas.
    • NRG Energy's (NRG +13%) Q3 net earnings fell by $203M, due to lower energy margins and costs related to paying down debt, on 11% less revenue of $3.95B; CEO Mauricio Gutierrez says its generation business "performed well during some very challenging market conditions."
    • Dynegy (DYN +8.6%) posted a Q3 loss of $249M, a 10x larger loss than in the year-ago quarter, saying it aims to navigate the low prices by buying plants and streamlining operations as well as ramping up lobbying efforts with regulators, including opposing New York's plan to subsidize money-losing nuclear power plants to keep them operating.
    • Calpine (CPN +2.7%) last week reported Q3 net earnings of $295M, up 8% Y/Y, but net profit for the first nine months of the year was just $68M, down 76% Y/Y.
    • Exelon (EXC +0.7%) has been faring better than some rivals since it also owns regulated utilities, which offer more stable profits.
    • "It's an adverse environment because of the low gas prices, and it's aggravated by the growth of renewables," says Hugh Wynne at investment research firm SSR.
    • ETFs: XLU, UTG, IDU, VPU, GUT, BUI, FUTY, RYU, UPW, FXU
     
     
     
     
    | 12:28 PM | 4 Comments

  • Consumer Goods - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 12:00 pm

    • Gainers: ELY +12%. FOSL +7%. MHK +6%. SYUT +6%. ICON +6%.
    • Losers: UEIC -17%. NUS -7%. SQBG -7%. SAFM -6%. PPC -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:00 PM
  • INT

    World Fuel Services upgraded to Buy at Stifel, mostly on valuation

    • World Fuel Services (INT +2.3%) is upgraded to Buy from Hold with a $48 price target at Stifel, which says shares have fallen precipitously and are now at an attractive level.
    • Stifel notes shares have shed more than 15% in the past week and now trade at the low end of the historical P/E range, but says a number of drivers could collectively generate 20%-plus earnings growth in 2017.
    • With a strong balance sheet and 10% free cash flow yield, the firm sees little downside risk from current levels.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:58 AM | 3 Comments
  • ALR

    Alere Q3 top line off 4%; non-GAAP EBITDA down 53%; shares down 12%

    • Alere (ALR -12.3%) Q3 results ($M): Total Revenues: 582.4 (-3.5%); Product & Services Revenue: 579.9 (-3.4%).
    • Cardiometabolic: 188.7 (-9.7%); Infectious Disease: 183.4 (+11.3%); Toxicology: 155.9 (-4.1%); Consumer Diagnostics: 19.3 (+3.2%).
    • Net Income: 16.5 (+314%); Non-GAAP EBITDA: 63.6 (-53.1%); EPS: 0.19 (+290.0%).
    • Related ticker: (ABT +2.1%)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:40 AM
  • IMPV

    Imperva +4%; Q3 over projections, review of alternatives concluded, restructuring planned

    • Results – revenue $68.4M (+8% Y/Y, $5.24M above estimates), EPS $0.08 ($0.24 above estimates), operating income $2.5M (vs. $6.7M Y/Y), net income $2.5M (vs. $6.3M Y/Y), total deferred revenue $116.6M (+28% Y/Y), net cash from operation $9.8M (vs. $10.5M Y/Y), free cash flow $4.2M (vs. $9.3M Y/Y), cash, cash equivalents and investments $259M
    • Segment revenues – Products and license $22.486M (vs. $30.451M Y/Y), Services $45.921M (vs. $32.898M Y/Y)
    • Strategic alternatives – Concludes review, remaining focused on business plan.
    • Restructuring – Intends to reduce sales, marketing, general and administrative expenses through employee cutback and less spending. Estimates annual savings at $15M and to be completed by the end of the quarter.
    • Q4 projections – revenue $69M-$71M, gross margin 81%, operating income $0.9M-$2M, net income $0.3M-$1.4M
    • FY 2016 projections – revenue $255.1M-$257.1M, gross margin 81%, $11.1M-$10M operating loss, $12.4M-$11.3M net loss, capital expenditures $18M-$20M, cash flows positive
    • Imperva (NASDAQ:IMPV) president and CEO Anthony Bettencourt: "During the quarter, we benefitted from the ongoing momentum of subscription revenue driven by our Incapsula business, as well as overall cost controls. We are confident in our ability to reaccelerate growth given the ongoing need for enterprises to protect their business-critical data and applications supported by our best-of-breed discovery, protection and compliance solutions."
    • Share price summary – 1-month, -32%; 3-month, -19%; 1-year, -50%
    • Prior quarters overview
    • Earnings call transcript
     
     
     
     
    | 11:28 AM
  • FRSH

    Papa Murphy's can't keep up with pizza peers

    • Papa Murphy's (FRSH -9.9%) slides after Q3 earnings miss expectations.
    • Domestic system comparable store sales fell 5.8% during the quarter, including a 5.6% drop at domestic franchisee-owned stores and a 7.7% decrease at company-owned stores.
    • The company's performance looks even shakier after factoring in the strong quarters from Domino's and Papa John's.
    • During the conference call, management said the elevated level of advertising rates tied to the Olympics and presidential election impacted its media spend.
    • Papa Murphy's earnings call transcript
    • Previously: Papa Murphy's misses by $0.08, misses on revenue (Nov. 2)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:21 AM
  • NE

    Noble Corp. -5% on weakness in floating rig utilization, fleet downtime

    • Noble Corp. (NE -5.1%) is sharply lower after posting a larger than expected Q3 loss and a 57% Y/Y revenue decline amid a decline in floating rig utilization and higher than expected fleet downtime.
    • NE says Q3 utilization of its 16 floating rigs was 41% vs. 51% in Q2, while fleet downtime was 6%, slightly higher than the 5% guidance; however, utilization of NE’s jackup fleet remained healthy at 80%.
    • Capex over upcoming quarters is seen averaging significantly below Q3 spending of $472M.
    • NE says it expects a significant reduction in operating costs next year, which combined with its backlog and fleet mix, should have a "meaningful" affect on its 2017 financial performance.

  • INNL

    Innocoll's Cogenzia flunks late-stage studies in diabetic foot ulcers; shares down 37% premarket

    • Thinly traded small cap Innocoll Holdings (NASDAQ:INNL) slumps 37% premarket on light volume in response to its announcement that pipeline candidate INL-002, branded as COGENZIA (gentamicin collagen topical matrix), failed to beat standard-of-care (SOC) treatment (systemic antibiotics and wound therapy) in two Phase 3 studies in patients with moderate-to-severe diabetic foot ulcers.
    • Neither trial, COACT-1 or COACT-2, met its primary endpoint of a statistically valid difference in clinical cure rate between the test group and SOC alone or SOC with placebo.
    • On the plus side, the company has submitted its New Drug Application (NDA) to the FDA seeking approval of XARACOLL (bupivacaine HCl collagen-matrix implants) for the treatment of postsurgical pain.

  • LCI

    Lannett responds to DoJ probe on earnings call

    • Not surprisingly, yesterday's Bloomberg article asserting DoJ charges would be filed against generic drugmakers before year-end was in focus on Lannett's (NYSEMKT:LCI) Q3 earnings call. (Lannett reported Q3 earnings yesterday afternoon).
    • Question: "I was hoping you could comment on whether anything's changed in the recent weeks or months regarding that probe into potentially collusive behavior?"
    • CEO Arthur Bedrosian said the BoD "was very proactive in making sure that outside counsel was brought in to thoroughly investigate the matter," and that after leaving "no stone unturned... they found absolutely no wrongdoing on the part of anybody in Lannett." Bedrosian said the search included laptops, phones, texts.
    • He also noted that the AG initially misunderstood LCI's products and assumed it made or marketed a doxycycline that it doesn't.
    • "At least here, if this thing is going to end at the end of the year or in January, then it's over and the shareholders of our company at least can be assured that Lannett was innocent of anything, and can have their confidence restored and maybe join the company as shareholders again. It's unfortunate that people read headlines and they don't know, and I understand that concern they have. But this should be finished finally after 2.5 years, and January would be about 2.5 years from the first inquiry from the Connecticut AG. So I'm kind of looking forward to that being the end. Because usually there's no final date when these things are over, so this deal is welcome in a way, of course not for the people that [ph] have been hit by the problem."
    • Shares of Lannett fell 26.6% yesterday.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:51 AM | 5 Comments
